THE SECOND QUEBEC CONFERENCE

Morgenthau Papers
 2llemorandatid by the Secretary of the Treasury (AMolrgenthau)1
 At a conference between the President and the Prime Minister, Mr.
Churchill said that he would sum up the discussion that we had been
having in regard to the future disposition of the IRuhr and the Saar.
lie said that they would permit Russia and any other of our Allies to
help themselves to whatever machinery they wished, that the indus-
tries in the Ruhr and in the Saar would be shut down, and that these
two districts would be put under anl international body which would
supervise these industries to see that they would not start up again.
 This progamme for eliminating the war-making industries in the
Ruhr and in the Saar is part of a programme looking forward to di-
verting Germany into largely an agricultural country.
 The Prime Minister and the President were in agreement upon this
programme.
 [QUEBEC,] Septem-iber 1.5, 1941.
 'The source copy bears the following typewritten endorsement: "Draft
I.
HMJr. dictated this."
 Morgenthau dictated this paper in the early afternoon of September 15,
1944,
when he and Cherwell withdrew from la Roosevelt-Churchill meeting for the
express purpose of putting in writing an agreed position on Germany for Roose-
velt and Churchill to approve. See ante, p. 361. Morgenthau and Cherwell
then
returned to the meeting of the Heads of Government and presented this paper,
which was not acceptable to Churchill. For the paper which Churchill then
dictated and which was initialed by Roosevelt and Churchill, see post, p.
466.
Roosevelt Papers: Telegram

T 0P SEClE T [QUEBEC,] 15 September 1944.
 Aeamorandum from the President for the Secretary of State.
 After many long conversations with the Prime Minister and Lord
Cherwell, the general matter of post-war plans regarding industries
